awd_titl_txt: Washington State Earth Sciences Summit: Pathways for Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
The Washington State Undergraduate Earth Sciences Summit will bring together geoscience faculty and staff from community and technical colleges (CTCs) and bachelors-granting universities across the state. The goal of the Summit is to develop a plan where Earth science majors have access to clear pathways that result in successful transfer within the state. Two-year colleges have the potential to be a source of increasing diversity of Earth science majors across the state. However, if the transfer process is unclear or inconsistent or does not effectively prepare students, there could be a bottleneck resulting in a decreasing number and diversity of bachelor's degree recipients. PIs anticipate that the partnerships and structures that will emerge from the Summit will improve both the number and diversity of successful students in geoscience programs. This Summit has the potential to develop a model that could be useful for other geoscience programs, including environmental science, meteorology, oceanography, agricultural and soil sciences, all programs which are generally discovered after students enter college. The Summit seeks to identify the unique barriers that may block transfer pathways in the Washington state system, and the solutions that reduce or remove these barriers that could be extrapolated and adapted nationally.

The Washington State Undergraduate Earth Sciences Summit will organize and convene a gathering of undergraduate faculty and advisors who will seek to  improve transfer pathways in Washington state. The Summit seeks to build a community of Earth science faculty in the State, and develop relationships between all undergraduate institutions that will facilitate the sharing of ideas and improvement of programs. Summit goals include (1) engagement of key stakeholders to foster discussions about Earth science opportunities through a lens of guided pathways and equity; (2) identification of threshold concept(s), competencies, and self-regulatory strategies that lead to successful transfer; (3) definition of successful transfer and identification of obstacles that impede students' progress in the Earth sciences; (4) exploration and initiation of future collaborations across colleges and institutions, and (5) identification of next steps for improvement of transfer processes at both the institutional level, between institutions, and in Washington state overall.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
We conducted a transfer summit to discuss how to best support Washington State student transfer in the Earth sciences. Two-year colleges have the potential to be a source of increasing diversity of Earth science majors across the state. However, the transfer process is currently unclear and inconsistent. This results in an increase in barriers to successful transfer which may be impacting the quantity and diversity of bachelor's degree recipients. 

The Washington State Undergraduate Earth Sciences Summit brought together geoscience faculty and advising staff from community and technical colleges (CTCs) and bachelors-granting universities across the state. The workshop included 33 attendees from 18 distinct community and technical colleges (CTCs) and 9 different 4-year colleges and universities (4YC/Us). The goal of the Summit was to develop a plan where Earth science majors have access to clear pathways that result in successful transfer within the state. Partnerships and structures emerged from the Summit that have the potential to improve both the number and diversity of successful students in geoscience programs. This Summit has developed a model that could be useful for other geoscience programs, including environmental science, meteorology, oceanography, agricultural and soil sciences, all programs which are generally discovered after students enter college. The Summit identified a series of barriers that block transfer pathways in the Washington state system, and have created some solutions to reduce or remove these barriers. Much of this work can be extrapolated and adapted nationally. 

The Summit built a community of Earth science faculty in the State, and developed relationships between most undergraduate institutions that facilitated the sharing of ideas and improvement of programs. Summit achievements included (1) engaging key stakeholders to foster discussions about Earth science opportunities through a lens of guided pathways and equity; (2) identification of threshold concept(s), competencies, and self-regulatory strategies that lead to successful transfer; (3) identification of obstacles that impede students' progress in the Earth sciences; (4) identification of next steps for improvement of transfer processes at both the institutional level, between institutions, and in Washington state overall and in some cases, (5) initiation of collaborations across colleges and institutions.

The collaborations initiated at the summit led to follow-up outcomes including the development and sharing of a transfer matrix/guide that highlights how much variation exists across the state for student transfer and supports students in greater understanding of their options. Another outcome of the summit was a virtual transfer information fair that has been organized and hosted by some of the participants, held annually in January that allows for 2YC students and faculty to learn about varying geology/Earth science 4-year programs across the state. 

Results of the project have been presented at four conferences, including the Geologic Society of America Annual Meeting and the AGU Fall Meeting. The project also developed a website that provides a template for others to use should there be interest in developing a similar summit: https://sites.google.com/highline.edu/wa-earth-sciences-summit/home.

 


Last Modified: 09/06/2024
Modified by: Katrien Kraft
